metadata.subject: biology
metadata.dotPoint: The inputs and outputs of the light dependent and light independent stages of photosynthesis in C3 plants

concepts.name: photosynthesis overview
concepts.formula: Photosynthesis synthesises organic compounds (glucose) from inorganic molecules (CO2, H2O) using light energy
concepts.correct: Correct! Photosynthesis is an anabolic process that converts light energy into chemical energy stored in glucose, using carbon dioxide and water as raw materials.

wrong.error: You confused the overall equation. Photosynthesis uses CO2 and H2O to make glucose and O2, not the reverse.
wrong.fix: 6CO2 + 6H2O + light → C6H12O6 + 6O2. This is the reverse of cellular respiration.
wrong.action: Photosynthesis: CO2 + H2O → glucose + O2. Respiration: glucose + O2 → CO2 + H2O.

wrong.error: You thought photosynthesis produces CO2. It CONSUMES CO2 and produces O2.
wrong.fix: Plants take in CO2 through stomata and release O2 as a waste product of photolysis.
wrong.action: Remember: Photosynthesis fixes carbon (takes CO2 in), respiration releases it.

wrong.error: You thought photosynthesis is catabolic. It's ANABOLIC—building glucose from small molecules.
wrong.fix: Anabolic = building up. Photosynthesis builds glucose from CO2 and H2O.
wrong.action: Photo-SYNTHESIS = building something new. Catabolism breaks things down.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the overall equation and nature of photosynthesis.
persistent.action: Write and balance the equation: 6CO2 + 6H2O + light → C6H12O6 + 6O2. Identify all inputs and outputs.

concepts.name: light dependent reactions
concepts.formula: Light reactions occur on thylakoids, using light to produce ATP, NADPH, and O2 from water
concepts.correct: Correct! The light-dependent reactions capture light energy to split water (producing O2), energise electrons for ATP synthesis, and load hydrogen onto NADPH.

wrong.error: You thought light reactions produce glucose. Light reactions produce ATP and NADPH; the Calvin cycle makes glucose.
wrong.fix: Light reactions: light → ATP + NADPH + O2. Calvin cycle: ATP + NADPH + CO2 → glucose.
wrong.action: Light reactions make 'energy currency' (ATP, NADPH). Calvin cycle 'spends' it to make glucose.

wrong.error: You thought light reactions occur in the stroma. They occur on thylakoid membranes.
wrong.fix: Thylakoid membranes contain photosystems and electron transport chains for light reactions.
wrong.action: Light reactions = membranes (photosystems). Dark reactions = fluid (enzymes in stroma).

wrong.error: You thought light reactions use CO2. CO2 is only used in the Calvin cycle, not light reactions.
wrong.fix: Light reactions: H2O in, O2 out. Calvin cycle: CO2 in, glucose out. Different inputs.
wrong.action: Water provides electrons/hydrogen for light reactions. CO2 provides carbon for Calvin cycle.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding what the light-dependent reactions produce.
persistent.action: List light reaction inputs (H2O, light) and outputs (O2, ATP, NADPH). Draw the process.

concepts.name: photolysis
concepts.formula: Photolysis splits water using light energy, releasing oxygen and providing electrons to replace those lost from chlorophyll
concepts.correct: Correct! Light energy splits water molecules (H2O → 2H+ + 2e- + ½O2), with electrons replacing those lost from chlorophyll and oxygen released as a waste product.

wrong.error: You thought oxygen comes from CO2. Oxygen comes from splitting WATER (H2O), not CO2.
wrong.fix: Photolysis (photo = light, lysis = splitting) breaks water. The oxygen in O2 comes from H2O.
wrong.action: H2O → 2H+ + 2e- + ½O2. The O in O2 comes from water, proven by isotope experiments.

wrong.error: You thought water provides carbon. Water provides hydrogen and electrons; CO2 provides carbon.
wrong.fix: Water splits to give electrons (for ETC), protons (for gradient), and oxygen (waste).
wrong.action: Carbon comes from CO2 (fixed in Calvin cycle). Hydrogen comes from H2O (in light reactions).

wrong.error: You thought photolysis occurs in the stroma. It occurs in the thylakoid lumen, associated with PSII.
wrong.fix: Photosystem II contains the water-splitting complex on the lumen side of thylakoid membranes.
wrong.action: PSII + light + H2O → electrons + protons (into lumen) + O2.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding where oxygen comes from in photosynthesis.
persistent.action: Draw the water-splitting reaction: H2O → 2H+ + 2e- + ½O2. Label where each product goes.

concepts.name: photophosphorylation
concepts.formula: Photophosphorylation uses light-energised electrons in an ETC to generate a proton gradient for ATP synthesis
concepts.correct: Correct! Energised electrons from chlorophyll move through the electron transport chain, pumping protons into the thylakoid lumen to drive ATP synthase.

wrong.error: You confused photophosphorylation with oxidative phosphorylation. Photo = light; oxidative = respiration.
wrong.fix: Photophosphorylation: light → ATP (in chloroplasts). Oxidative phosphorylation: food → ATP (in mitochondria).
wrong.action: Both use ETC and chemiosmosis, but energy source differs: light vs chemical.

wrong.error: You thought ATP is made directly by chlorophyll. ATP is made by ATP synthase using the proton gradient.
wrong.fix: Chlorophyll captures light → electrons energised → ETC → proton gradient → ATP synthase → ATP.
wrong.action: Chlorophyll captures energy. ATP synthase makes ATP. They're different molecules with different roles.

wrong.error: You thought protons accumulate in the stroma. They accumulate in the thylakoid lumen.
wrong.fix: Protons are pumped INTO the lumen, then flow OUT through ATP synthase into the stroma.
wrong.action: Lumen = acidic (high H+). Stroma = less acidic. H+ flows down gradient through ATP synthase.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding how light energy is converted to ATP.
persistent.action: Draw the process: chlorophyll → excited electrons → ETC → proton gradient → ATP synthase → ATP.

concepts.name: NADPH production
concepts.formula: NADPH is produced when NADP+ accepts electrons and protons at the end of the electron transport chain
concepts.correct: Correct! At Photosystem I, electrons are re-energised and transferred to NADP+, which combines with H+ to form NADPH for use in the Calvin cycle.

wrong.error: You confused NADPH with NADH. NADPH is used in chloroplasts; NADH is used in mitochondria.
wrong.fix: NADPH has an extra phosphate and is used for biosynthesis (anabolism). NADH is for respiration (catabolism).
wrong.action: NADPH = building carrier (photosynthesis). NADH = energy carrier (respiration).

wrong.error: You thought NADPH provides energy for the ETC. NADPH is a product that carries electrons TO the Calvin cycle.
wrong.fix: NADPH carries 'reducing power' (electrons + H+) from light reactions to Calvin cycle.
wrong.action: NADPH is loaded in light reactions, unloaded in Calvin cycle. It's a transport molecule.

wrong.error: You thought NADPH is made at PSII. NADPH is made at PSI, which comes later in the pathway.
wrong.fix: PSII: splits water, starts electron flow. PSI: boosts electrons for NADP+ reduction.
wrong.action: PSII → ETC → PSI → NADP+ reductase → NADPH. PSI is needed for high-energy electrons.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding NADPH's role as an electron/hydrogen carrier.
persistent.action: Draw the pathway: PSII → ETC → PSI → NADP+ + H+ → NADPH. Show where electrons come from.

concepts.name: calvin cycle overview
concepts.formula: The Calvin cycle uses ATP and NADPH to fix CO2 into glucose in the stroma
concepts.correct: Correct! The Calvin cycle is the light-independent stage where carbon dioxide is fixed and reduced using ATP and NADPH from the light reactions to produce glucose.

wrong.error: You thought the Calvin cycle produces ATP. It CONSUMES ATP (and NADPH) to make glucose.
wrong.fix: Calvin cycle inputs: ATP, NADPH, CO2. Outputs: glucose (and ADP, NADP+, Pi to recycle).
wrong.action: Light reactions MAKE ATP/NADPH. Calvin cycle USES them. They're complementary.

wrong.error: You thought the Calvin cycle needs light directly. It needs products of light reactions (ATP, NADPH).
wrong.fix: Called 'light-independent' because it doesn't use light directly—but still needs light reaction products.
wrong.action: No ATP/NADPH from light reactions = Calvin cycle stops. Indirectly dependent on light.

wrong.error: You thought the Calvin cycle occurs on thylakoids. It occurs in the stroma where Rubisco is dissolved.
wrong.fix: Thylakoids = membranes for light reactions. Stroma = fluid for Calvin cycle enzymes.
wrong.action: ATP/NADPH travel from thylakoids to stroma. CO2 enters stroma from air.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding what the Calvin cycle needs and produces.
persistent.action: List Calvin cycle inputs (ATP, NADPH, CO2) and outputs (glucose, ADP, NADP+, Pi).

concepts.name: carbon fixation
concepts.formula: Rubisco catalyses carbon fixation by combining CO2 with RuBP to form unstable 6C compounds that split into GP
concepts.correct: Correct! Rubisco fixes CO2 onto RuBP (5C), forming an unstable 6C compound that immediately splits into two molecules of GP (3C each).

wrong.error: You thought Rubisco makes glucose directly. Rubisco makes GP; further steps convert GP to glucose.
wrong.fix: Rubisco: CO2 + RuBP (5C) → 2 GP (3C each). GP is then reduced to TP, which makes glucose.
wrong.action: Rubisco is step 1 (carbon fixation). Glucose is the final product after several more steps.

wrong.error: You confused GP with glucose. GP is a 3-carbon intermediate; glucose is 6 carbons.
wrong.fix: GP (glycerate-3-phosphate) is 3C. Two TP molecules combine to eventually make one glucose (6C).
wrong.action: GP (3C) → TP (3C) → two TP → glucose (6C). Multiple steps and molecules involved.

wrong.error: You thought CO2 is fixed in the light reactions. Carbon fixation is part of the Calvin cycle in the stroma.
wrong.fix: Light reactions: water splitting, ATP/NADPH production. Calvin cycle: CO2 fixation.
wrong.action: CO2 enters the Calvin cycle, not the light reactions. Different stages, different functions.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding the role of Rubisco in carbon fixation.
persistent.action: Write the Rubisco reaction: CO2 + RuBP (5C) → 2 GP (3C). Explain each molecule.

concepts.name: TP and glucose
concepts.formula: TP (triose phosphate) is used to synthesise glucose or regenerate RuBP using ATP
concepts.correct: Correct! GP is reduced to TP using ATP and NADPH. Most TP regenerates RuBP; some is used to make glucose and other organic molecules.

wrong.error: You thought all TP becomes glucose. Most TP (5 out of 6) regenerates RuBP to keep the cycle going.
wrong.fix: For every 3 CO2 fixed: 6 TP made, 5 TP → RuBP regeneration, 1 TP → half a glucose.
wrong.action: The cycle must continue! Most TP recycles. Only the 'profit' becomes glucose.

wrong.error: You thought TP is made without ATP. Reducing GP to TP requires both ATP and NADPH.
wrong.fix: GP + ATP + NADPH → TP + ADP + NADP+ + Pi. Both carriers are needed.
wrong.action: ATP provides energy, NADPH provides hydrogen/electrons. Both from light reactions.

wrong.error: You thought two TP directly become glucose. TP forms G3P, which can be exported or combined into glucose.
wrong.fix: TP (also called G3P) can be used to make glucose, amino acids, lipids, or other organic compounds.
wrong.action: TP is a versatile building block. Glucose is just one possible product.

persistent.gap: You're not understanding how products of the Calvin cycle are used.
persistent.action: Draw the Calvin cycle showing: CO2 → GP → TP → (most to RuBP, some to glucose).

light-dependent.title: Introduction to Light Reactions
light-dependent.instructions: Learn the basics of light-dependent reactions.

sentences.text: Photosynthesis is a two-step process where the light {{d1}} reactions convert light energy into {{d2}} energy.

d2.tooltip: Energy stored in ATP and NADPH

sentences.text: The light-dependent reactions occur on the {{d1}} membranes within stacks called {{d2}}.
The products of light reactions include {{d1}}, NADPH, and {{d2}} which is released as a waste product.

photolysis-etc.title: Water Splitting and Electron Transport
photolysis-etc.instructions: Understand photolysis and the electron transport chain.

sentences.text: Light is absorbed by {{d1}}, which is split by photolysis into hydrogen ions, electrons, and {{d2}}.
Energised electrons from chlorophyll enter an electron {{d1}} chain, which uses their energy to pump {{d2}} into the thylakoid lumen.

d2.tooltip: H+ ions that create the gradient

sentences.text: ATP is produced via {{d1}} when protons flow through {{d2}} synthase back into the stroma.

calvin-cycle.title: Introduction to the Calvin Cycle
calvin-cycle.instructions: Learn the basics of the light-independent reactions.

sentences.text: The light-{{d1}} reactions use ATP and NADPH to fix carbon dioxide and produce {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Reactions that don't need light directly

sentences.text: The Calvin cycle occurs in the {{d1}}, where the enzyme {{d2}} fixes carbon dioxide.
Carbon dioxide is combined with a 5-carbon molecule called {{d1}} to form a 3-carbon compound called {{d2}}.

integration.title: Connecting the Two Stages
integration.instructions: Understand how the stages of photosynthesis connect.

sentences.text: The light reactions produce {{d1}} and NADPH, which are used by the Calvin cycle to fix {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Gas fixed in the Calvin cycle

sentences.text: Hydrogen from {{d1}} (via NADPH) combines with carbon from CO2 to form organic molecules like {{d2}}.
The overall equation for photosynthesis shows that {{d1}} and water plus light produce glucose and {{d2}}.

light-dependent.title: Photosystem Details
light-dependent.instructions: Apply understanding of how photosystems function.

sentences.text: Photosystem {{d1}} acts first, splitting water and releasing energised {{d2}} into the electron transport chain.

d1.tooltip: Despite the numbering, which acts first

d2.tooltip: Particles that travel through the ETC

sentences.text: Electrons from water replace those lost from {{d1}} when light is absorbed by the {{d2}} centre.

d2.tooltip: Where electrons are excited and transferred

sentences.text: Photosystem {{d1}} re-energises electrons and transfers them to {{d2}} reductase for NADPH synthesis.

d1.tooltip: The second photosystem in the pathway

photolysis-etc.title: Chemiosmosis in Chloroplasts
photolysis-etc.instructions: Apply understanding of how the proton gradient drives ATP synthesis.

sentences.text: As electrons move through the ETC, their energy is used to pump protons from the {{d1}} into the thylakoid {{d2}}.
The accumulation of protons creates an {{d1}} gradient, also called the proton {{d2}} force.

d1.tooltip: Type of gradient across the membrane

sentences.text: Protons flow through ATP {{d1}} back into the stroma, driving the synthesis of ATP from ADP and {{d2}}.

calvin-cycle.title: Calvin Cycle Steps
calvin-cycle.instructions: Apply understanding of the Calvin cycle mechanism.

sentences.text: Rubisco catalyses the reaction between CO2 and {{d1}} (a 5C molecule), forming an unstable {{d2}} intermediate.

d2.tooltip: Number of carbons in the unstable intermediate

sentences.text: The unstable 6C compound immediately breaks into two molecules of {{d1}}, which is then reduced to {{d2}} using ATP and NADPH.
Most TP molecules are used to {{d1}} RuBP, while some are used to synthesise {{d2}} and other organic molecules.

integration.title: Energy and Material Flow
integration.instructions: Apply understanding of how energy and materials move through photosynthesis.

sentences.text: Light energy is converted to {{d1}} energy in ATP and then to {{d2}} energy in glucose.

d1.tooltip: Form of energy in ATP bonds

d2.tooltip: Form of energy stored in glucose

sentences.text: ADP and {{d1}} are recycled from the Calvin cycle back to the thylakoids to be recharged by {{d2}} reactions.

d2.tooltip: What powers ATP and NADPH regeneration

sentences.text: The oxygen released during photosynthesis comes from {{d1}}, not from carbon dioxide, as shown by {{d2}} tracer experiments.

d2.tooltip: Method used to trace oxygen origin

light-dependent.title: Analysing Light Reaction Efficiency
light-dependent.instructions: Evaluate factors affecting light reaction efficiency.

sentences.text: The {{d1}} spectrum shows that photosynthesis is most efficient when plants receive red and {{d2}} light.

d1.tooltip: Graph showing photosynthesis rate vs wavelength

sentences.text: Cyclic {{d1}} only involves Photosystem I and produces ATP but no {{d2}} or oxygen.
Non-cyclic electron flow produces both ATP and NADPH, with electrons ultimately coming from {{d1}} and ending in {{d2}}.

photolysis-etc.title: Evaluating Electron Transport
photolysis-etc.instructions: Evaluate the role of the electron transport chain.

sentences.text: Without the electron transport chain, protons could not be pumped against their concentration {{d1}}, and no {{d2}} gradient would form.
Electron carriers in the ETC include plastoquinone and {{d1}}, which are embedded in the {{d2}} membrane.
The chemiosmotic theory explains ATP synthesis in both chloroplasts and {{d1}}, using similar {{d2}} mechanisms.

d2.tooltip: What drives ATP synthesis in both

calvin-cycle.title: Calvin Cycle Stoichiometry
calvin-cycle.instructions: Evaluate the carbon balance in the Calvin cycle.

sentences.text: To produce one molecule of glucose (6C), the Calvin cycle must fix {{d1}} molecules of CO2 and complete {{d2}} turns.
For every 3 CO2 fixed, 6 molecules of TP are produced, but only {{d1}} can leave the cycle as net {{d2}}.
Each turn of the Calvin cycle requires {{d1}} ATP and {{d2}} NADPH molecules to reduce and regenerate intermediates.

integration.title: Photosynthesis in Context
integration.instructions: Synthesise understanding of photosynthesis as a complete process.

sentences.text: Photosynthesis is the foundation of most food chains because it converts {{d1}} energy into {{d2}} energy stored in organic molecules.
Glucose produced by photosynthesis can be converted to {{d1}} for storage or broken down by {{d2}} for energy release.
The products of photosynthesis (glucose, O2) are the {{d1}} of cellular respiration, demonstrating the {{d2}} nature of these pathways.
